title: The One Sheet: Spring 2016 Fashion Trends to Watch
text:
1 COMMENTS The Global Theater
International relations have rarely been so chic. From left: Alexander McQueen’s Indian mirror work through a Victorian lens, Junya Watanabe and Valentino go sub-Saharan and Proenza Schouler’s refined take on dramatic Spanish style.
ENLARGE Photo: Getty Images (Marc Jacobs) Flag Time
The classic—and patriotic for some—color combination of red, white and blue captured a range of creative minds. From left: Giorgio Armani hits a nautical note, Marc Jacobs says it in sequins and Chanel gets playful with airmail hues at its clever airport-themed runway show.
ENLARGE Excess Story
The fashion appetite for clothes that artfully pile on embellishment and print is at an all-time high. From left: Dries Van Noten’s neo-Hollywood glam, Gucci’s ’70s show and Prada’s layered lady.
ENLARGE Photo: Paul Wetherell (Bally) Natty and Neutral
How to find a moment of serenity amid the trend storm? Beautifully tailored silhouettes in buttery shades. From left: Derek Lam’s textured trench, sporty elegance at Hermès, Bally’s sharp lines and the relaxed but still refined silhouette at the Row.
ENLARGE Photo: Paul Wetherell (Bally) Bedroom Community
Designers pushed spring’s inherent softness, blurring the line between boudoir and boulevard. From left: dreamy satin at Balenciaga, Haider Ackermann’s tougher take, Céline’s sharp slip, going gauzy at Christian Dior and Givenchy’s masculine twist.
ENLARGE Photo: MCV Photo (Sacai); Dan and Corina Lecca (Alexander Wang); Getty Imagse (Louis Vuitton); Fabien Monntique (Off-White) Concrete Visions
The newest thread: clothes that merge high-fashion ideas with cues from the urban street. From left: Sacai’s wild style, sporty stripes at Alexander Wang, Louis Vuitton’s digital denim, jean genius from Marques’Almeida and Off-White’s patched-up perfection.
When the Show’s the Thing
On the runways, it was a big season for spectacle
HE HAD ME at the Junior Mints. No, wait, it was the Milk Duds. It was hard to choose a snack from the abundant, free selection at the Marc Jacobs spring 2016 show, staged in mid-September as a tongue-in-cheek film premiere at Manhattan’s grand Ziegfeld Theater. Oh, and there were clothes, lively fantastic looks streaming down a mock red-carpet.
Every season, naysayers sound the death knell for live runway shows. But there are a few things they don’t know. One is that a fashion show can make you feel something, like Givenchy’s rather touching presentation in New York, held on Sept. 11 on a west side pier from which you could see the Tribute in Light’s twin beams. A gamble? To say the least. But designer Riccardo Tisci and his collaborator, artist Marina Abramović, turned the proceedings into something beautiful rather than crass.
One man who will never doubt the power of the show is Chanel’s Karl Lagerfeld. This season he transformed Paris’ cavernous Grand Palais into a delightful Chanel-logoed airport, with models rolling suitcases that matched their looks.
And at New York designer Alexander Wang’s bittersweet last collection for Balenciaga, Mr. Wang juxtaposed churchly environs with a can’t-not-dance-to-it hip-hop soundtrack consisting of Biggie Smalls and Tupac.
The biggest shocker happened off the runway, however: the appointment of Vetements co-designer Demna Gvasalia as Mr. Wang's successor. Mr. Gvasalia, whose floral dress and reconstructed jeans were street-style favorites this month, held his own low-production show in a slightly gritty Chinese restaurant in Paris. Frenzied as a mosh pit, it was one of the most buzzed-about of the week, proving you don’t need a huge budget to make a show soar.
